name: The Self Modifying Maker 2.0
description:
The second version of this deck. Got a lot of good feedback from my first attempt, and have shifted my build. Added more efficient breakers to the suite, with a focus on being able to crack any server, even if R&D is the initial focus.

I believe this version has a stronger end game, which the original suffered in.

As always, feedback welcome!

name: You just have to know where to look!
description:
First Deck I am uploading.

While this is the third or fourth Deck I built, I do not have much experience of any kind (having roughly played 10 games so far) - most of what I (think I) know is theoretical...

I know that this Deck has a lot of redundancies in it (regarding Tutoring and Econ), but I don't know if or what I could cut out. I played it once, and it ran really well. However, this is not even close to me being able to see how well the Deck works.

But since I will not see much play, anyways (no more than 1-2 games per week, maybe less), I thought I'd put it out there. To see what you guys come up with, to make it even better...

name: Tag - you're it!
description:
First Deck I built, and second Deck I upload here.

I have no idea how well it works, as I have played it only once, and that was before the last changes I took on the Deck list. It would need serious playtesting, but I will only be able to play once or twice a week, and it's even likely that I'll play less (e.g. no game at all during the last 2 weeks). So I don't see me getting enough experience in with this deck to hone it better...

...so I'm throwing it to you guys. Maybe you can give me some pointers as to what or how to improve here. I already improved my initial list based on suggestions on BGG, and some other thoughts...

The deck is a little big, and cutting 5 cards would probably help, but I cannot see what to cut. So maybe you got some suggestions there, too?

Oh, maybe as an aside - I do not want to go DAMAGE in any way with this deck. Which is why there is no Scorched in here, nor Dedicated, nor any other measure of that kind...

name: Chaos Theory Wunderbuild 4.0
description: Tweeked after reading Pinkwarrior and x3r0h0ur suggestions.

name: Runner#3 (Economic) mod+
Haas Bioroid BrainPain
Andi Link
description:
This is a deck type i've been working on for some time now keep trying it not been happy giving up then going back later trying new approach and tweaking it.

Finally got a version that's running well that am happy with so i thought id post it.

name: CS: Anarch "Noise" v.0.2
description: Core set, anarch, variant 1

name: NBN - Ghostwriting a Thrupenny Dreadful (Hobo Fast Advance)
description:
Still the same principle as before, everything must cost three credits or less. I have switched out closed accounts and red herrings for Bernice Mai (more tags please) and ghost branch (even more tags please). Ghost branch operates on the principle of being either a brilliant way to set up a Psycho-Beale score (as it masquerades as a Beale remarkably well) or if it doesn't fire, a trick of light battery that doesn't weaken my ice.

Overall the deck remains brutal and able to slam out agendas at a staggering rate of knots. And to explain the name to any Americans who aren't familiar with older British coinage, a thrupenny is the nickname for the old three pence coin that is now no longer used.

name: SneakyKit
description:
Inspired to build this thanks to Refractor and GPWK's deck here: http://netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/7618/prismatic-peddler

The deck is built around Refractor, which is a super-efficient and aggressive breaker that scales well, and only has the caveat of needing a stealth credit to work, of which there are 9 sources in the deck. Dagger fills the same kind of role.

I've kept Demolition Run along with my multiaccess cards, and I've reintroduced Woman in the Red Dress, which is a very fun and powerful card that lets you focus your one run each turn for a guaranteed agenda in R&D or a good chance of getting one in HQ.

name: Kate: Big Money / Slow Monolith Rig
description: 1st Runner Deck;

name: Neo Hessians v.1.0
description: This is basically an attempt to leverage the massive influence of Custom Biotics: Engineered for Success to make a more powerful version of Red Coats. This version tried to use Simone Diego as run bait and added econ (allowing the corp to use it's liquid funds for ICE while still advancing) but that was too disjointed. Thomas Haas was also intended as run bait that would pay me if they came through my server, didn't like it. GRNDL Refinery is back breaking on a taxing server. They either run the gauntlet and create a scoring windows or they leave it alone and give the corp a lot of money. Added bonus that it is slightly more expensive to trash than Melange Mining Corp.. Ultimately, this was a failed build.

name: Neo Hessians v.1.1
description:
This is a refinement of Neo Hessians 1.0 that removed the extraneous run bait of Simone Diego and Thomas Haas. This allowed me to add a 3rd Tollbooth and I brought in Interns to either stack a server cheap or pull a dead Jackson Howard or GRNDL Refinery from my Archive.

Eve Campaign also was brought in to bring in that sweet, sweet clickless econ and act as a tax on the runner that will actually kill her. The only other card I got rid of was my singleton Hudson 1.0, it wasn't right for this build.

Play this like Red Coats and grind the runner into dust.

This build was way more solid than its original, but I wasn't happy with the ICE. Curtain Wall was a prime example... on to v1.2.

name: Trick or Track
description:
Try to get Future Perfect scored before anything else as Runner usually does not care much to run on advanced card if you got 0 pts in your score area and they got a lot of other options to do on their turn.

Force all the 1 pointers down the Runners throat as much as you can by simply install, install, install.. if they don't bite - then start to take those 1 pointers for yourself if you need the agenda bonus effect or if it's starting to look like you could actually win by scoring 7 points.

Other than that.. your main focus is to Fast Track for Philotic and Fast Advance to kill shot when the runner does not have enough cards in hand as agendas scored.

I've not tested this deck in any tournament setting, but overall it does win me some 7/10 games and the game-play feels refreshing for me at least :)

Version 0.3

name: Neo Hessians v.1.2
description:
So, this version swapped 1 Project Vitruvius for 1 Accelerated Beta Test. Solid choice with Interns already in the deck.

ICE changes. Curtain Wall was replaced by Hadrian's Wall. Hadrian's is cheaper and much more versatile. I never once got CW to drop from an ABT and I already have Wotan to do much of the same job. Rototurret was ok, but I was more happy to see Caduceus in the early game and it was not as much Parasite bait as Roto.

Run as a Red Coats deck. Bait the run with GRNDL Refinery and drain them dry. Deck is solid.

name: Obligatory Professor Deck
description:
Some cool interactions here.

  • Eureka + Test Run
  • Motivation + Eureka
  • Motivation + Oracle May
  • Freelance + Clone Chip (or Test Run)
    • Note: You only need to trash 2 programs for freelance = sure gamble
  • Monolith! (most importantly, avoid brain/net damage)
  • Scavenge + Femme|Imp|Anything

Mulligan for Test Run or Opus (and if you're stuck with a diesel you have an ok chance to draw Test Run or Opus

At that point you have to just react to the situation. The immense amount of recursion means you can run with little to no fear (so long as you have a hand). End game is probably getting medium or nerve agent going. Keyhole against scary R&D decks.

name: Whizzard Anti-FA DT
description:
This is João Almeida's (Hraklea) deck for this BGG forum that I'm trying out: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1180200/anarch-vs-nbn-what-i-learned-after-40-matches-in-o

Some of his notes:

  • Against NBN, it doesn't matter how many Xanadus and Rooks your Reina Roja manage to install, you'll never hurt the Corp as much as Whizzard (Howard + SanSan = free trashes) and Parasites on Pop-up Windows do. Astro/Biotics is too fast to waste time playing chess. Whizzard is boss here.

  • Account Siphon is broken, I know. But NBN, due Sweeps Week and Shipment from SanSan, can avoid it by staying low on credits. A smart player will do that. Also, an ICE in HQ might prevent me from getting my credits in a key moment of the match. When your opponent is fast as Astro/Biotics is, you can't afford to have your main economy card denied like that.

  • Nerve Agent is a monster in this match up. Multi HQ access forces the Corp to protect HQ in a deck that doesn't have a lot of ICEs. It is a must have if you expect to have any reliable chance of winning against NBN.

  • Hemorrhage is terrible in this match up. I still like the card against Haas-Bioroid and Weyland, but it is probably the worse card in the game against NBN. Even Disrupter is more useful.

  • Burst economy is more important than end game economy. Cards like Magnum Opus and Desperado are not worth their influence cost in this match up.

  • Captain obvious here, but using Frame Job to slow NAPD Contract down is not worth it. Even when you forfeit a Breaking News. I tested it!

  • Demolition Run makes Medium faster and transforms Nerve Agent in a killer machine. It took a little while, but Demolition Run is finally a scary card. I won't remove them from my deck any time soon.

name: Hobo Anarchist
Whip out the Wyrm
description:
I used this deck at the Bern regionals in Switzerland. It won 3 of my 4 match-ups (got scorched once by the tournament winner), performing much better than I expected!

The idea is parasite recursion, relying on Wyrm to bring the ice strength down to 0 rather than Datasucker tokens (although when available, Datasucker tokens make it cheaper). With Magnum Opus and Stimhack, I generally had enough credits to go in and blow up all the ice. Installing a couple The Personal Touches makes the Wyrm much more efficient.

For already rezzed ice, Parasites can be recurred with Test Run. But most of the parasites were installed at instant speed with Clone Chip, Personal Workshop, and Self-modifying Code.

Why 1xThe Toolbox? 5 MUs is good enough for a Magnum Opus, a Wyrm, a Parasite, and one more program: usually Nerve Agent for me. But I usually let it sit on Personal Workshop so that I can bring it out if it makes sense to femme something or if I need the Inti for a wraparound. The recurring credits can be used for lowering ice strength. Finally, it's nice to have something big on Personal Workshop so that you can put a Parasite on it and control exactly when it comes out (and have something to do with unused stimhack credits when the corp doesn't rez anything).

Atman was a last minute addition I made in case I ever ran out of Parasites. A player at the tournament (who ran Parasite recursion Kate suggested Crypsis for breaking ice once in order to rely less on instant Parasite installs.

It's important to keep drawing while using this deck. One SMC, a parasite on personal workshop, and a clone chip means you can kill all the ice on a 3-deep server. After this, you need to be able to get set up again faster than the Corp can draw new ice. It helps that some ice becomes meaningless. Two of my opponents rezzed inazumas, which have no effect on this deck. And a 2-deep server with chum means you spend a couple extra credits and 2 net damage to make the chum useless (and if it's a 0-strength ice, then you can kill it after it's rezzed but before encountering it and chum has no effect). I never had to use Levy AR Lab Access, but it should ensure you can keep up the pressure after the clone chips are gone.

As for changes, I will probably switch to Indexing instead of R&D Interface. It's possible that this deck is strictly worse than other parasite recursion decks out there, but it's definitely a blast to play... even if just to see the look on their faces when you whip out the Wyrm!

name: Inside Kate's Mind
Faction Challenge: Gabe Central Punishment
description:
This is part of the Faction Challenge deck series, in which I attempt to create a deck for every faction using only two core sets and one of each data pack and big box expansion.

The idea here is to run hard, focusing on central servers, using the new central Icebreakers from H&P.

name: Decimator Web
description:
Ghostly streams of data criss-cross the net in unending complexity like malevolent spider webs underneath the sanctioned data streams. No two of these webs are exactly alike, but they are all deadly. Behind each web lies a glimmer of valuable information, hiding almost in plain site but for the haze of bits protecting it. Runners who enter don't always leave. Some say you can hear the hollow shells of their minds crying out in pain if you venture too close. Best just to avoid them altogether...

There's an almost infinite number of tricks you can pull with the combinations of ice in here. The key is to be constantly repositioning with Tenma Line. Use Minelayer and Bullfrog to help cheat ice into those expensive upper slots. Midori is also nice to spring a surprise trap in their face. The trick is to present an ever-shifting web of ice that if the runner runs into they won't be guaranteed to come out alive. This is helped along by Jinteki: Replicating Perfection, which gives the runner only three vectors to run for his first run. You can easily lay a trap on each one, or maybe just a trap on one and two Bullfrog on the other...

name: Back to Basics
Andy
